title: Verbs and prepositions
introduction: Do you know how to use the prepositions for, from, in, of, on, to and with after verbs? Test what you know with interactive exercises and read the explanation to help you.
explanation: When a verb is part of a longer sentence, it is often followed by a specific preposition.
keyPoints: a verb is part of a longer sentence, it is often followed by a specific preposition
you make so much noise, I can't concentrate on my work
examples: Do you know how to use the prepositions for, from, in, of, on, to and with after verbs?
Look at these examples to see how prepositions are used after verbs.
Can you wait for me to finish my lunch?
Grammar explanation
When a verb is part of a longer sentence, it is often followed by a specific preposition.
She listens to the radio a lot.
There are no grammatical rules to help you know which preposition is used with which verb, so it's a good idea to try to learn them together.
He apologised for being late.
I applied for the job but I didn't get it.
How do you ask for a coffee in Polish?
I can't go out tonight because I have to prepare for my interview tomorrow.
Verbs with from
This spray should protect you from mosquitoes.
Has he recovered from the accident yet?
Verbs with in
She doesn't believe in coincidences.
Our company specialises in computer software.
You have to work hard if you want to succeed in life.
Verbs with of
I don't approve of hunting animals for their fur.
